questions.question: Question 1: Which among the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the spleen?

options.a: The spleen develops from the ventral mesogastrium
options.b: The axis of the spleen lies along the 9th rib
options.d: The spleen is partly covered by the peritoneum

questions.explanation:
The superior border of the spleen is notched. The superior border of the spleen separates the diaphragmatic surface from the gastric impression 
of the visceral surface. It often contains one or two notches. Additionally, there can be a notch on 
the inferolateral border, and this may be palpated only when the spleen is enlarged. Option A: The spleen arises from the primitive mesoderm as an outgrowth of the left side of the 
dorsal mesogastrium. Option B: The spleen is related to the 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs, with its long axis along the 10th rib. Option D: The spleen is completely intraperitoneal. 788 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: The downward displacement of the spleen is prevented by which of the following ligaments?
questions.explanation:
The phrenocolic ligament prevents the downward displacement of the spleen. The phrenicocolic ligament is not attached to the spleen. It attaches the splenic flexure of the 
colon to the diaphragm. When the spleen gets enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament along with the 
splenic flexure of the colon restricts its downward displacement.The enlargement of the spleen 
occurs towards the right iliac fossa and is directed obliquely. Splenic ligaments and their attachments: Splenic ligament

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is the most common site for an accessory spleen?
questions.explanation:
The most common site for accessory spleen or splenunculi is the splenic hilum. It is the most 
common anomaly of splenic embryology. Other locations for accessory spleen in descending order of frequency are: • Gastrocolic ligament • Pancreatic tail • Greater omentum • Greater curvature of the stomach 790 
Sold by @itachibot • Splenocolic ligament • Small and large bowel mesentery • Left broad ligament in women • Left spermatic cord in men

questions.question:
Question 4: A 55-year-old lady presents with complaints of epigastric and lower back pain. Past history is 
significant for post-traumatic splenectomy at the age of 12 years. CT scan showed multiple 
nodules scattered across the intestinal loops and under the diaphragm. The tumours were 
excised following laparotomy and histology was typical for splenic tissue. What is the likely 
diagnosis? 783 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of splenosis. Splenosis refers to the rupture of the spleen and distribution of splenic tissue on the 
peritoneum. This should be considered as a differential diagnosis when a patient with a splenic 
injury in the past presents with tumour-like lesions on abdominal imaging.

questions.question:
Question 5: Two weeks following an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old child presents with a 
skin rash as shown in the image. She also complains of bleeding gums and her platelet count 
is 18,000/µL. Which among the following is false about her condition?

options.a: Chronic form of this condition is more common in females
options.c: Bone marrow examination shows increased megathrombocytes
options.d: Splenectomy is the best alternative treatment for this condition

questions.explanation:
The image showing petechiae and the given history of a child presenting with mucocutaneous 
bleed following an upper respiratory tract infection are highly suggestive of immune 
thrombocytopenic purpura. In idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), the spleen is palpable in fewer than 10% 
of the patients, and the presence of gross splenic enlargement should raise the suspicion of an 
alternative diagnosis. Management of ITP: • In patients with platelet counts <30,000/L, treatment may be instituted if there are 
symptoms of life-threatening bleeding. • Prednisone at 1 mg/kg is the initial treatment of choice. • Rh(D) immune globulin is used only in Rh-positive patients. • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG). • Splenectomy is indicated in patients who have relapsed on glucocorticoid therapy. Relapse 
patients with intermittent or high platelet count can be managed with anti-Rh0(D) 
immunoglobulin, IVIG, or with a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. • Subcutaneous romiplostim and oral eltrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonists used in 
adults who are at risk of bleeding even after splenectomy. Option A: The acute form is more commonly seen in children following a viral infection, while the 
chronic form is more often seen in adult women of childbearing years. Option C: The bone marrow examination can be normal or show an increased number of 
megathrombocytes. Option D: 80% of cases undergo spontaneous remission in children. Patients who do not respond 
to first-line therapy like steroids and IVIG are best treated by splenectomy. 791 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A young man with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura is posted for splenectomy. His 
platelet count is 32000 per cubic millimeter. What is the best time to transfuse platelets in 
this patient?

options.b: Immediately after the ligation of splenic artery
options.c: Immediately after the ligation of splenic vein

questions.explanation:
The best time to transfuse platelets in this patient is immediately after ligation of the splenic 
artery. The platelets are destroyed by the spleen within one hour of transfusion, and the splenic artery is 
the major vessel that brings blood to the spleen. Therefore, the best time to transfuse the platelets 
is immediately after the ligation of the splenic artery.

questions.question: Question 7: In a patient with hypersplenism, which of the following features can not be seen?
questions.explanation: Bone marrow failure is not seen in a patient with hypersplenism. Hypersplenism is an indefinite clinical syndrome that is characterised by: • Splenic enlargement • Combination of anemia, leucopenia or thrombocytopenia • Compensatory bone marrow hyperplasia • Improvement after splenectomy.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is false?

options.a: Schistosomiasis can lead to tropical splenomegaly
options.c: Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia
options.d: Howell-Jolly bodies are seen in asplenia

questions.explanation:
Thrombocytosis occurs following splenectomy. This occurs particularly in patients with myeloproliferative disorders (e.g., chronic myeloid 
leukemia, polycythemia vera, essential thrombocytosis). It may result in thrombosis of the 
mesenteric, portal, and renal veins which can be life-threatening as it can lead to haemorrhage 
and thromboembolism. Option A: Tropical splenomegaly is massive splenic enlargement, which frequently occurs in the 
tropics due to malaria, kala-azar, and schistosomiasis. Option C: Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and 
hereditary spherocytosis. Option D: Howell-Jolly bodies are the nuclear remnants present in the RBCs. They appear as 
dense blue colored circular inclusions as shown in the image below. They are usually seen in 
patients lacking normal spleen function (asplenia). 792 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A young male patient who is on treatment for osteomyelitis was found to have multiple 
splenic abscesses. This patient is least likely to have which of the following?
questions.explanation: Splenomegaly is not a typical feature of splenic abscess. Splenic abscesses manifest with vague abdominal pain, fever, peritonitis, and pleuritic chest pain. A splenic abscess may arise from an infected splenic embolus, or in association with: • Typhoid or paratyphoid fever • Osteomyelitis • Otitis media • Puerperal sepsis.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the most common indication for splenectomy?
questions.explanation:
Overall, the most common indication for splenectomy is trauma to the spleen, whether external 
(blunt or penetrating) or iatrogenic (e.g., during operative procedures for other reasons). The most common indication for: • Elective splenectomy - Haematological disorders such as ITP, TTP, etc. • Emergency splenectomy - Trauma • Splenectomy (overall) - Trauma.

questions.question:
Question 11: What is the most common complication that is expected to occur in patients following 
splenectomy?

options.b: Avascular necrosis of greater curvature of stomach

questions.explanation:
Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after splenectomy. 793 
Sold by @itachibot Other complications of splenectomy include: • OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)is the most common fatal late complication of 
splenectomy. • Avascular necrosis of the greater curvature of the stomach is a rare complication that can occur 
after ligation of short gastric vessels. • Damage to the tail of the pancreas during surgery can lead to pancreatitis, a localized abscess, or 
pancreatic fistula. • Hemorrhage during the perioperative period etc.

questions.question:
Question 12: Vaccine for post-splenectomy infection is given against all except  
.
questions.explanation:
Escherichia coli vaccination is not recommended in post-splenectomy patients. Currently, the standard of care for post-splenectomy patients includes immunization with the 
following if the patient did not receive these before surgery: • Polyvalent pneumococcal vaccine (PPV23) • Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate vaccine • Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the statements regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection are correct?
questions.explanation:
The risk of developing opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is greatest when splenectomy is 
done for haematological conditions than for post-trauma. Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is a major complication following splenectomy due to 
septicemia, which may result from an infection of: • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common) • Neisseria meningitides • Haemophilus influenzae • Escherichia coli. The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy. Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against 
pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) 
(repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery. In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after 
recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 24-year-old professional football player was tackled hard during a match. He complains of 
severe pain in the left upper abdomen. On examination, his BP is 100/74 mm Hg and there is 
tenderness and crepitus over the left 10th and 11th ribs. He also complains of pain over the 
left shoulder when pressure is applied over the left upper abdominal quadrant. This sign is 
called: 786 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
794 
Sold by @itachibot Kehr sign refers to referred pain in the tip of the left shoulder when firm pressure is applied over 
the left upper quadrant. It is also elicited by raising the left leg. It is seen in the case of hemoperitoneum, especially due to splenic injury. It occurs due to the 
collection of blood below the diaphragm and irritation of the phrenic nerve. Option A: Ballance sign is also seen in splenic injury. It is an area of percussive dullness in the left 
upper quadrant due to the coagulation of blood from the injured spleen. Option B: Cullen sign refers to periumbilical bruising in cases of hemoperitoneum, especially 
those of pancreatic origin. Option D: Grey Turner sign refers to bluish discolouration around flanks in case of 
hemoperitoneum especially acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis. 795 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following statements regarding splenic artery aneurysms is true?

options.a: It is the most common visceral artery aneurysm
options.b: The most common presentation is severe epigastric pain
options.c: Rupture is more common during the second trimester of pregnancy
options.d: All diagnosed cases require surgical intervention

questions.explanation:
Splenic artery aneurysm is the commonest visceral artery aneurysm. Splenic artery aneurysm occurs more commonly in females. It is usually situated in the main 
arterial trunk. It is usually asymptomatic unless it ruptures. During pregnancy, rupture is more 
common in the third trimester and in labour. CT angiography is the investigation of choice. Not all diagnosed cases of splenic artery 
aneurysms need intervention. Treatment should be considered in aneurysms larger than 2 cm in diameter. In an elderly patient with a calcified aneurysm, there is less risk of rupture and observation may 
be preferred. In a younger patient with an asymptomatic aneurysm, surgery or interventional 
radiology is indicated. In patients with pancreatic necrosis, the treatment should include drainage of the septic focus. The treatment comprises of: • Ligation of the proximal and distal ends of the sac • Embolization or endovascular stenting • Splenectomy with the removal of the artery

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is the most common cyst of the spleen?
questions.explanation:
The most common splenic cyst is pseudocyst, secondary to trauma. These are termed pseudocysts 
due to their lack of cellular lining. Splenic cysts are classified as either parasitic or non-parasitic: • Parasitic/hydatid cysts are the most common true/primary splenic cysts • Splenic pseudocysts are the most common non-parasitic splenic cysts and occur following 
trauma • Epidermoid cysts are the most common non-traumatic, non-parasitic splenic cysts. Note: These epithelial cells are often positive for CA 19-9 and carcinoembryonic antigen by 
immunohistochemistry. Patients with splenic epidermoid cysts may have elevated serum levels of 
one or both of these tumor markers.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following statements regarding tumors of the spleen is true?

options.d: Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose

questions.explanation:
The most common primary tumor of the spleen is hemangioma. Option A: Lymphoma (not Hemangiosarcoma) is the most common malignant primary tumour of 
the spleen. Option C: Ovarian carcinoma is the most common cause of isolated splenic metastasis 796 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Lymphoma is the most common cause of neoplastic splenic enlargement and the most 
common malignant tumour associated with splenic involvement. 797
